ä½ mlgbçš„ï¼ŒåˆæŠŠç®€ä¸­æä¸Šï¼Œä½ ä»–mlgbçš„ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªåƒç›¸å¤ªé¸¡å·´éš¾çœ‹äº†ï¼Œæˆ‘æ“ä½ å¦ˆï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬çš„é’±ä¸æ˜¯é’±æ˜¯å§ï¼Ÿä½ å¦ˆä¸ªé€¼çš„ï¼Œæ€ä¹ˆä½ è¿˜ä¸æ­»ï¼Œæˆ‘å°±ç›¼æœ›ç€ä½ æ­»ï¼Œå¥¶å¥¶çš„ï¼Œä½ è¿™ä¸ªå·®è¯„æˆ‘ç»™å®šäº†ï¼Œæˆ‘è¿˜æ¢ç€å·ç»™ï¼Œå¤§ä¸äº†è€å­ä¹°å·ï¼Œæˆ‘ç»™ä½ åˆ·å·®è¯„ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ä½ ä¸ªé¸¡å·´ä¸œè¥¿é…å—ï¼Ÿè€å­åœ¨ä½ èº«ä¸ŠèŠ±é’±ï¼Œä¸€åˆ†é’±æˆ‘éƒ½å¿ƒç–¼ï¼Œæ“ä½ å¦ˆçš„

Having played 22 competitive seasons in a row during Overwatch 1's lifetime, I genuinely believe that the developers love Overwatch, I really do, but it's hard to justify giving this game your attention, money, or hard-drive space.

Activion-Blizzard had every chance to make this a strong IP and reasonable alternative to Team Fortress 2. Yet, what we got is an unrewarding, predatory, heavily sanitized, centralized-matchmaking game with very few opportunities for getting to know people or getting to express yourself, and Joss Whedon-esque puppets masquerading as rich characters.

If you like Team Fortress 2, you have a few options to choose how to play. You can try out one of Valve's matchmaking services, you can hop into a community server and get to know people or look for some custom content, or if you'd like you have the tools to create content yourself.

Overwatch offers a lot of things that are superficially similar, but ultimately fall short of being fulfilling.

Their balancing approach does not allow you to freely swap between weapons and classes like one might in Team Fortress 2, but also there's a secondary "open queue" in competitive mode that you can register for. Even if you want to play competitive, there are two different queues going into two fundamentally different experiences.

In the most technical sense there are custom matches that could theoretically satisfy the same purpose as TF2's custom servers, even having a reasonably robust "workshop" that makes programming your own gimmicks and gameplay modes very accessible (UNO has been playable in Overwatch for years!), but the server infrastructure is built around a basically immutable 6v6 limit. The crazy 32-player (and more recently, 100-player) servers you see in Team Fortress 2 do not exist here.

Custom graphical assets and maps also fundamentally do not exist here; there are no surf maps, no CS/L4D/TF2 ports, no custom sprays, nothing. Activision-Blizzard does contract third-party artists to create character skins for them, but it's nowhere near as accessible as the Team Fortress 2 workshop is.

These might all be *okay* for people who want that kind of mastercrafted "play our game exactly as we intend it" kind of shooter that's so popular nowadays, but unfortunately it does not stop there.

Once upon a time it was possible to earn cosmetics in Overwatch simply by playing. You'd get them randomly, you could save up in-game cash to get the stuff you really liked, and there were also a few methods for quick-and-easy drops like weekly Arcade wins. That is no longer the case; Overwatch 2 thrives on selling cosmetics for exorbitant amounts of real money. There are some absolute winners, no doubt, but a legacy Overwatch account is now worth thousands because of how drastic this monetization change was (if you had absolutely everything at the time of Overwatch 2's launch, your account costs more than two Golden Frying Pans.)

They have also locked hero unlocks behind their battlepass system which, of course, is structured to incentivize spending money. You can pay money for an actual competitive edge over somebody else by unlocking a hero instantly, whereas Team Fortress 2's weapons are reasonably accessible, but those locked behind achievements can be unlocked effortlessly through achievement maps and the assistance of friends.

More critically is that promises related to Overwatch simply have not been kept. Overwatch 1 was sold under the premise that they would never charge for heroes, so they announced a "sequel" that also included Player vs. Enemy event missions. That didn't sound that bad at the time, there were a slew of seasonal events that showed off that this game had serious potential as a PvE experience, but the insidious truth was that this "sequel" existed to allow Activision-Blizzard to radically reinvent their monetization strategy. What's worse, the promised Player vs. Enemy campaigns simply would never come. Aaron Keller, director of Overwatch 2 (replacing Jeff Kaplan from Overwatch 1), unceremoniously confirmed to GameSpot one day that Hero Mode simply would not live up to what was promised (several sources even described it as being *canceled*.)

Activision-Blizzard did eventually whip up a short wave of co-op Story Missions in the new Invasion DLC, but they charge $15 for the privilege of permanent access (previous content in this style has historically been free but time-limited) to what is essentially a bad Left 4 Dead clone with superheroes.

Doing horrible things to AI while playing overpowered heroes feels gratifying, but it's not worth the monetary investment that Activision-Blizzard wants from you, and the multiplayer is continuously exhausting even in casual queues; you are always responsible for 20% your team's performance. You *must* perform well.

If you've got low standards for a co-op or competitive shooter, then, sure, Overwatch 2 is a free option that is sufficient enough to waste your time, but after everything I've experienced in this game they should probably be paying me instead.

Tried this shitty game to see what it would be like
The graphics settings make the game look terrible and the game still runs like shit, I run tf2 on high settings and rarely experience any sort of slowdown.
The tutorial was so bad that I would have preferred if the game hadn't given me one. It was just "Athena" giving me captain obvious tips like "if your health reaches 0 you die" 
Most of the heroes are locked behind the "hero challenges" (which the game gives 0 explanation on) or are behind a battle pass

if you read this: go play tf2, it's free as well and frankly, it's a much better experience
